meanings.def: a word or words that a particular person, animal, place or thing is known by
examples: What's your name?
What is/was the name, please? (= a polite way of asking somebody’s name)
Please write your full name and address below.
Leave your name and number (= phone number) and we'll call you later.
Are you changing your name when you get married?
She uses her married name at work.
The singer's real name is Bob Rich.
His full name was William Augustus Grove.
His father was a painter of the same name.
Do you know the name of this flower?
name for something Rubella is just another name for German measles.
under a… name The company reopened under a new name.
My name is Maria.
His name is Tom Smith.
John T. Harvey
Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Hello, Maria.
Hello, Mr Brown.
Thank you, Doctor.
This is his second book published under his own name.
Many postures use the names of animals, like cat, dog or crab.
‘Does that name mean anything to you?’ ‘Yes, it does ring a bell (= it is familiar).’
As the name implies, Oxford was the place at which oxen could ford the river.
He invoked the name of Freud in support of his argument.
He was elected Pope in 1978 and took the name of John Paul II.
He's been in four movies with Spielberg's name attached.
His name is synonymous with the worst excesses of sixties architecture.
His name sounds familiar.
His name was immortalized in 1992 when he scored three goals in the space of five minutes.
His wife and sister share the same name, Sarah.
How do you know my name?
I asked him his name.
I do not want my name associated with these products.
I have a bad memory for names and faces.
I'm afraid I've forgotten your name.
I'm sorry, I didn't catch your name.
I've heard that name mentioned before.
Muhammad Ali's birth name was Cassius Clay.
Nobody puts (= gives) their name to a business they are not proud of.
She uses a different name in her professional life.
She was given the name Maria, after her grandmother.
Somebody called out her name from below.
St Petersburg has gone back to its original name.
The Brady bill acquired its name from its best-known sponsor, James Brady.
The Julian calendar was introduced by Julius Caesar and hence carries his name.
The common name for the flower is ‘pineapple lily’.
The island is more commonly known by the name ‘Krakatoa’.
The name of the artist appears on the vase.
The scientific name for plants in this genus is Asclepias.
The village of Low Catton takes its name from the Old English personal name ‘Catta’.
Their original band name was ‘Cherry Five’
They put his name forward as one of the five candidates for the post.
We cannot mention the suspect's name for legal reasons.
Where does the band name come from?
The name's Bond.

meanings.def: a reputation that somebody/something has; the opinion that people have about somebody/something
examples: She first made her name as a writer of children's books.
He's made quite a name for himself (= become famous).
The college has a good name for languages.
This kind of behaviour gives students a bad name.
There was a campaign to blacken his name.
These practices give the industry a bad name.
We must avoid anything that might damage the good name of the firm.
They tried to protect the good name of the college.
This kind of behaviour gives students a bad name.
Throughout his years in prison, he fought to clear his name.
He accomplished a remarkable feat in restoring the name of the bank to something like its former eminence.
The area got a bad name after a series of nasty murders.
The company has a name for reliability.
The riots after the match only served to blacken the name of football.
He made his name writing travel books.
These articles have damaged the good name of the newspaper.

meanings.def: having a name or a reputation of the kind mentioned, especially one that is known by a lot of people
examples: a big-name company
brand-name goods

meanings.def: a famous person
examples: He is a big name in the world of rock music.
Some of the biggest names in the art world were at the party.
The event attracted many famous names from the past.
The movie needs some names in it, if it’s going to be successful.

meanings.def: to be called something
examples: The dog was an ugly brute, answering to the name of Spike.

meanings.def: used to say that somebody has a lot of a particular quality
examples: ‘Patience’ is my middle name!

meanings.def: an important person
using the name of somebody/something
examples: She asked for you by name.
The principal knows all the students by name.
I only know her by name (= I have heard about her but I have not met her).
The head teacher knows every child in the school by name.

meanings.def: who is called
examples: a young actor by the name of Tom Rees

meanings.def: to use offensive words about somebody
examples: Stop calling me names!

meanings.def: to criticize or say bad things about somebody in public, in a way that is unfair
examples: The paper has dragged his name through the mud.
They feel their agency has been dragged through the mud by the press.
Football's good name is being dragged through the dirt.

meanings.def: to mention famous people you know or have met in order to impress others
examples: She found him rather irritating to talk to; all he did was drop names.

meanings.def: to apply for a place at a school, in a competition, etc. for somebody or yourself
examples: Have you entered your name for the quiz yet?
They’ve already put his name down for Eton College.
Have you put your name down for the school play?

meanings.def: when a person already has a bad reputation, it is difficult to change it because others will continue to blame or suspect them
to discover or invent something which then becomes known by your name
examples: Henry Hudson gave his name to New York's Hudson River.
The invading Franks gave their name to the country in which they settled.
The Huron people gave their name to one of the Great Lakes.
Charles Macintosh gave his name to a type of raincoat.

meanings.def: to use a name that may not be your real one
examples: a thief who goes by the name of ‘The Cat’
He goes by the name of Jonno.

meanings.def: if something has your name on it, or there is something with your name on it, it is intended for you
examples: He took my place and got killed. It should have been me—that bullet had my name on it.
Are you coming for dinner this evening? I've got a steak here with your name on it!

meanings.def: used to describe a situation which exists in reality but that is not officially recognized
examples: He runs the company in all but name.

meanings.def: used especially in questions to show that you are angry, surprised or shocked
examples: What in God's name was that noise?
Where in the name of Heaven have you been?

meanings.def: for somebody; showing that something officially belongs to somebody
examples: We reserved two tickets in the name of Brown.
The car is registered in my name.
The account is in joint names.
The tickets were booked in the name of McLean.

meanings.def: using the authority of somebody/something; as a representative of somebody/something
examples: I arrest you in the name of the law.

meanings.def: used to give a reason or an excuse for doing something, often when what you are doing is wrong
examples: crimes committed in the name of religion

meanings.def: officially recognized but not existing in reality
examples: He's party leader in name only.

meanings.def: to let it be known in public that you support or agree with something
examples: I am more than happy to lend my name to this campaign.

meanings.def: to have a place named after you
used to say that somebody is not liked or popular because of something they have done
examples: Your name’s mud around here at the moment!
If you tell our secret your name will be mud round here.

meanings.def: to give the names of the people involved in something, especially something wrong or illegal
examples: He has accused the government of corruption and claims he is prepared to name names.
Detectives believe that a hitman was sent to silence the witness before he could name names.

meanings.def: the most important aspect of an activity; the most important quality needed for an activity
examples: Hard work is the name of the game if you want to succeed in business.

meanings.def: a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field
examples: Miyazaki is still a name to conjure with among anime fans.

meanings.def: used when you mention a name that you think is difficult to remember or pronounce
examples: He comes from Tighnabruaich—now there's a name to conjure with!

meanings.def: to know or remember what somebody/something is called
examples: I recognize the tune but I can't put a name to it.
I nodded, desperately trying to put a name to the face.

meanings.def: to have a name that sounds funny
examples: He rejoiced in the name of Owen Owen.

meanings.def: what is important is what people or things are, not what they are called
to show a lack of respect when using somebody’s name or when talking about them
examples: (humorous) Have you been taking my name in vain again?
to take the Lord's name in vain

meanings.def: to have or own something
examples: an Olympic athlete with five gold medals to his name
She doesn’t have a penny/cent to her name (= she is very poor).

meanings.def: using a name that may not be your real name
examples: The room was booked under a false name.

idioms.idiom: answer to the name of something
idioms.def: to be called something
examples: The dog was an ugly brute, answering to the name of Spike.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody has a lot of a particular quality
examples: ‘Patience’ is my middle name!

idioms.def: an important person
using the name of somebody/something
examples: She asked for you by name.
The principal knows all the students by name.
I only know her by name (= I have heard about her but I have not met her).
The head teacher knows every child in the school by name.

idioms.def: who is called
examples: a young actor by the name of Tom Rees

idioms.def: to use offensive words about somebody
examples: Stop calling me names!

idioms.idiom: drag somebody through the mud/dirt | drag somebody's name through the mud/dirt
idioms.def: to criticize or say bad things about somebody in public, in a way that is unfair
examples: The paper has dragged his name through the mud.
They feel their agency has been dragged through the mud by the press.
Football's good name is being dragged through the dirt.

idioms.def: to mention famous people you know or have met in order to impress others
examples: She found him rather irritating to talk to; all he did was drop names.

idioms.def: to apply for a place at a school, in a competition, etc. for somebody or yourself
examples: Have you entered your name for the quiz yet?
They’ve already put his name down for Eton College.
Have you put your name down for the school play?

idioms.idiom: give a dog a bad name
idioms.def: when a person already has a bad reputation, it is difficult to change it because others will continue to blame or suspect them
to discover or invent something which then becomes known by your name
examples: Henry Hudson gave his name to New York's Hudson River.
The invading Franks gave their name to the country in which they settled.
The Huron people gave their name to one of the Great Lakes.
Charles Macintosh gave his name to a type of raincoat.

idioms.def: to use a name that may not be your real one
examples: a thief who goes by the name of ‘The Cat’
He goes by the name of Jonno.

idioms.idiom: have your/somebody’s name on it | with your/somebody’s name on it
idioms.def: if something has your name on it, or there is something with your name on it, it is intended for you
examples: He took my place and got killed. It should have been me—that bullet had my name on it.
Are you coming for dinner this evening? I've got a steak here with your name on it!

idioms.def: used to describe a situation which exists in reality but that is not officially recognized
examples: He runs the company in all but name.

idioms.idiom: in God’s/Heaven’s name | in the name of God/Heaven
idioms.def: used especially in questions to show that you are angry, surprised or shocked
examples: What in God's name was that noise?
Where in the name of Heaven have you been?

idioms.idiom: in the name of somebody/something | in somebody’s/something’s name
idioms.def: for somebody; showing that something officially belongs to somebody
examples: We reserved two tickets in the name of Brown.
The car is registered in my name.
The account is in joint names.
The tickets were booked in the name of McLean.
I arrest you in the name of the law.
crimes committed in the name of religion

idioms.def: officially recognized but not existing in reality
examples: He's party leader in name only.

idioms.def: to let it be known in public that you support or agree with something
examples: I am more than happy to lend my name to this campaign.

idioms.def: used to say that somebody is not liked or popular because of something they have done
examples: Your name’s mud around here at the moment!
If you tell our secret your name will be mud round here.

idioms.def: to give the names of the people involved in something, especially something wrong or illegal
examples: He has accused the government of corruption and claims he is prepared to name names.
Detectives believe that a hitman was sent to silence the witness before he could name names.

idioms.def: the most important aspect of an activity; the most important quality needed for an activity
examples: Hard work is the name of the game if you want to succeed in business.

idioms.def: a person or thing that is well known and respected in a particular field
examples: Miyazaki is still a name to conjure with among anime fans.
He comes from Tighnabruaich—now there's a name to conjure with!

idioms.def: to know or remember what somebody/something is called
examples: I recognize the tune but I can't put a name to it.
I nodded, desperately trying to put a name to the face.

idioms.def: to have a name that sounds funny
examples: He rejoiced in the name of Owen Owen.

idioms.idiom: a rose by any other name would smell as sweet
idioms.def: what is important is what people or things are, not what they are called
to show a lack of respect when using somebody’s name or when talking about them
examples: (humorous) Have you been taking my name in vain again?
to take the Lord's name in vain

idioms.def: to have or own something
examples: an Olympic athlete with five gold medals to his name
She doesn’t have a penny/cent to her name (= she is very poor).

idioms.def: using a name that may not be your real name
examples: The room was booked under a false name.

meanings.def: to give a name to somebody/something
examples: name somebody/something (after somebody) He was named after his father (= given his father's first name).
name somebody/something (for somebody) The planet Mars is named for the Roman god of war.
name somebody/something + noun They named their son John.
adv. + named He plays the evil scientist, the aptly named Dr Weird.
Rust fungus is so named because of its rusty-coloured spots.
I named my son after my father.
the diesel engine, named after its inventor Rudolf Diesel
The hospital was named in honour of its principal benefactor.
The present Kew Bridge was opened by King Edward VII and is correctly named ‘King Edward Bridge’.
The ship will be officially named by the Queen before setting sail from her home port.
the aptly named Dare Devil
the dead sister for whom she had been named
the curiously named Egg Castle

meanings.def: to say the name of somebody/something
examples: name somebody/something The victim has not yet been named.
He refused to name his accomplice.
Can you name all the American states?
The manager has named his side for the semi-final.
He correctly named the song from the clip played.
name somebody/something as somebody/something The missing man has been named as James Kelly.
She was able to identify her attacker.
I recognized him as soon as he came in the room.
The victim has not yet been named.
I could just make out a figure in the darkness.

meanings.def: to state something exactly
examples: Name your price.
They're engaged, but they haven't yet named the day (= chosen the date for their wedding).
Activities available include squash, archery and swimming, to name but a few.
Chairs, tables, cabinets—you name it, she makes it (= she makes anything you can imagine).

meanings.def: to choose somebody for a job or position
examples: name somebody as something I had no hesitation in naming him (as) captain.
name somebody (to something) When she resigned, he was named to the committee in her place.
name somebody to do something Mr Shah has been named to run the new research unit.
the newly named head coach
The President officially named Kirk as his choice to replace Timms.
She was recently named to the company's board of directors.

meanings.def: to publish the names of people or organizations who have done something wrong or illegal
examples: Businesses which fail in their duty to protect the environment should be named and shamed.

meanings.def: to give the names of the people involved in something, especially something wrong or illegal
examples: He has accused the government of corruption and claims he is prepared to name names.
Detectives believe that a hitman was sent to silence the witness before he could name names.

idioms.def: to publish the names of people or organizations who have done something wrong or illegal
examples: Businesses which fail in their duty to protect the environment should be named and shamed.

idioms.def: to give the names of the people involved in something, especially something wrong or illegal
examples: He has accused the government of corruption and claims he is prepared to name names.
Detectives believe that a hitman was sent to silence the witness before he could name names.
